title: Squadrons start flying 150,000 Thomas Cook customers back to UK
text:
Squadrons of government-chartered aircraft have begun flying 150,000 stranded Thomas Cook customers back to the UK after the 178-year-old tour operator collapsed under the weight of its debts, leaving 9,000 UK staff facing redundancy.

Thousands of holidaymakers were left waiting for the state-backed airlift in airports from the US to mainland Europe and north Africa, after last-ditch talks for a £1.1bn financial rescue fell apart.

Meanwhile, hundreds of thousands of customers’ bookings for holidays and flights have been cancelled, including dream weddings.

Recriminations also flew after the government turned down the company’s request for £150m to help tide it over the winter.

Labour and trade unions criticised the decision to allow the company to plunge into liquidation, in one of the most high-profile corporate failures in British history. But No 10 said it could not justify spending taxpayers’ money to keep a struggling business afloat.

Airline regulator the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) has chartered more than 40 aircraft to bring customers home from 18 countries, after Thomas Cook’s own planes were grounded because of its collapse. The largest repatriation effort in peacetime history, dubbed Operation Matterhorn, is expected to incur costs of more than £100m, borne by the Department for Transport.

The prime minister, Boris Johnson, said authorising an emergency cash injection of £150m to stave off the company’s collapse would have set a dangerous precedent. “Clearly, that’s a lot of taxpayers’ money and sets up […] a moral hazard in the case of future such commercial difficulties that companies face,” he said.

A No 10 spokeswoman added: “A bailout would not have been a good use of taxpayers’ money. We would have had to repatriate people later down the line and have lost more money in the process.”

But Labour’s shadow chancellor, John McDonnell, said ideological bias was behind the decision. He told the BBC: “The government’s intervention could have enabled us to just stabilise the situation, give a breathing space so that there could be proper consultation with the workforce in particular about how to go forward.

“To just stand to one side and watch this number of jobs go and so many holidaymakers have their holiday ruined, I just don’t think that’s wise government.”

The first signs rescue talks had failed came on Sunday when executives left crunch talks with banks and shareholders without reaching a deal. The tour operator’s lights had disappeared from price comparison websites such as Skyscanner within hours.

The last Thomas Cook flight, from Orlando to Manchester, touched down at 8.52am at Manchester airport on Monday morning. Its crew were said to have been in tears. By that time officials from the CAA had already arrived during the night to impound one of its planes.

Passengers on one of the last official Thomas Cook flights, from Lanzarote to London Gatwick, praised the behaviour of cabin crew who knew their jobs were at risk.

Joe Jeness, 34, said: “After we touched down the crew were visibly upset. One of the air hostesses had tears in her eyes when we got off the plane and we saw others hugging each other. The captain came and stood at the exit with the crew and every passenger who got off the plane wished them well. It was heartbreaking.”

Facebook Twitter Pinterest British passengers speak to Thomas Cook staff at Palma de Mallorca airport. Photograph: Francisco Ubilla/AP

Staff at the company’s Peterborough headquarters were formally notified on Monday morning. “It is a matter of profound regret to me and the rest of the board that we were not successful,” said the chief executive, Peter Fankhauser. “This marks a deeply sad day for the company.”

The government’s insolvency service is expected to fund redundancy payments for UK staff, although trade union sources said it was unclear if they would be paid next week and predicted taxpayers would end up funding £50m in redundancy and compensation costs.

The fallout is already spreading far beyond the UK, with holiday resorts that rely heavily on British custom also bracing for hardship. On the island of Crete, where about 20,000 Thomas Cook customers were staying when it collapsed, officials likened the effect to an earthquake. Michalis Vlatakis, the head of Crete’s tourist agencies’ association, said hoteliers are expecting a “following tsunami” in the form of cancelled bookings for months ahead.

Tunisia’s government offered assurances holidaymakers won’t be prevented from leaving the country, following reports tourists were held prisoner at a hotel by staff who feared they would not be paid.

The cost of repatriating Britons who were overseas when Thomas Cook failed is expected to exceed the £60m spent on bringing people home after the failure of Monarch airline. Whitehall officials predict costs in excess of £100m.

After Monarch’s bankruptcy, the government pledged to overhaul airline insolvency rules, to protect passengers and the taxpayer from bearing the brunt of the cost in the event another airline went bust.

A review published in March recommended laws be changed so a bankrupt airline could be put in special administration to fly its own customers home, rather than have its planes grounded.

The review also recommended a 50p levy per passenger for a flight protection scheme – similar to the Atol system used at present – but covering all travellers. The then transport secretary, Chris Grayling, promised to swiftly introduce the changes but legislation has yet to be tabled.

Thomas Cook was in need of a financial restructuring as it buckled under the weight of a £1.7bn debt pile racked up during its 2007 merger with MyTravel and a subsequent acquisition spree that has since been heavily criticised. Deals include the 2010 high street travel agency tie-up with Co-op, which increased the number of high street shops it had to 1,200, even as customers were increasingly buying holidays online.

Thomas Cook nearly collapsed the following year and had to be rescued by its lenders, leading to it rack up even higher debts.

One company insider said the company had spent £1.3bn on making interest payments since then. This meant that of the 11m holidays it sold each year, the profit from 3m of them was going directly to its banks.

The debt burden restricted the company efforts to adapt to the internet age – it had 560 shops on the UK high street – and made it more vulnerable to short-term shocks that affected bookings.

These include terror attacks and political upheaval in north Africa, high jet fuel prices and last summer’s heatwave, which persuaded people across the UK and Thomas Cook’s vital Scandinavian market to stay at home and soak up the sun. Thomas Cook has 21,000 staff and, at the time of collapse, had about 600,00 customers abroad including British, Scandinavian and German holidaymakers.

Thomas Cook also cited the negative impact of Brexit uncertainty when it reported a £1.5bn loss earlier this year.

While staff, holidaymakers and tourism resorts suffered the fallout from its collapse, some winners are already emerging from Thomas Cook’s demise. Shares in its main competitor, Tui, were up nearly 7% in early trading, while easyJet, which is laying on some of the repatriation flights and also competed on low-cost routes, gained 3%.

Hedge funds that bet against Thomas Cook are also understood to have made tens of millions of pounds.

Airlines that competed with Thomas Cook have already begun hiking prices. These include including Virgin Atlantic, which increased the cost of a flight from Manchester to Orlando, Florida, next summer from £890 to £1242 overnight.

Chinese tourism company Fosun, which was prepared to inject £450m into Thomas Cook as its largest shareholder, said: “Fosun is disappointed that Thomas Cook Group has not been able to find a viable solution for its proposed recapitalisation.”

Banks and hedge funds were due to provide another £450m but the proposal collapsed after banks, led by Royal Bank of Scotland, demanded the company find another £200m.

In a joint statement lenders, including RBS, said they were deeply disappointed that Thomas Cook could not be rescued. They insisted they had supported the company, even as it haemorrhaged £1bn of cash over the past year.
description: Holidaymakers left waiting in airports around the world for state-backed airlifts home
